the outbreak of the civil war may thus be summed up :— What Cicero hoped for was an arrangement (compositio, concordia). Anything should be surrendered rather than have war.1 War will bring the tyrannis. Therefore Cicero hesitates, and does not openly j0in Pompeius, whose flight from Italy he condemns, while he despises the in- capacity, dilatoriness, oowardioe (almost) of his supportem. Moreover, peace is what Cicero most desires: now peace Pompeius will not have ε ² he even fears 112.ss Yet Cicero hopes he will be able to influence Pompeius.4 On the other hand, Caesar is very powerful, very active, and very conciliatory. But Cicero says ‘ he is running a- muck ' (ruit) 3 he is perditus ,· he is a tyrannus ,· his acts are furor, scelus. If war is unavoidable, Cicero must join Pompeius3 not to do so would be inglorious, dis- honourable, ungrateful. Yet, again, to think of the recklessness of the Optimates and the violence which would follow their victory. No matter: Pompeius alone moves Cicero ; the acts of him and his side have been a tissue of blunders: but his side is the right one. ‘ Mihi σκάφος,’ he writes, Att. vii. 3, 5, ‘unum erit quod a Pompeio gubernabitur!
